author: ChildofAlanWatts
body:
I worked in unity in school for animation.  It's a great software.  I still work in the 3d area and I love their all in one approach.  If I worked for the company I would be advocating to split the software into a suite and license it like auto autodesk or Adobe. 

I'm putting this on my watch.  May take a small position friday.

I have a lower limit buy of $75 but i doubt it will drop there.

My buy order didn't go through on IPO.  i really really want this stock

&#x200B;

edit\* what construction company do you work for?  i'm curious how your stock is performing.

author: lordjonas88
body: Autodesk long too getting killed

author: PuffyPanda200
body:
Sorry if I wasn't clear, there are other companies that provide different tools that are seemingly similarly dominant in their industry (not data analysis).

A really good example would be Autodesk (ADSK). They make the AutoCad family, REVIT and other tools, all for construction design. They are very dominant in this field and it would be very difficult for competitors to break in for a variety of reasons. ADSK trades at a 52 P/E ratio and about 20 P/R ratio. I think they are a bit overvalued and Yahoo seems to agree with me. I wouldn't stay they are a bad buy though. This company is only valued at ~2 times PLTR but looks way better. Another example would be ANSYS (ANSS) that makes FEA software. 

PLTR provides what one would hope is a dominant data analysis suite/tools. That's great but I am just not sure that they will find enough customers that sit in the 'goldilocks zone' of having enough data to analyze and not having the resources to create the tools themselves. I am also not entirely certain that companies that run systems like CRM services can't provide similar tools with other items. Salesforce, Google, and Microsoft all advertise data analytics. How would a customer know if the Palantir tools are better or worse than those produced by other larger companies that the customer may already have a relationship with (CRM, Microsoft suite, G-suite, etc.)?

author: dvdmovie1
body:
>  I think auto desk would just be like a tech stock.

It is, but as something that's larger and profitable, that's likely to hold up mildly better/be less volatile than "rapidly growing but unprofitable" (which has done horribly this year.)

" it just updates the software so people have to buy the subscription."

I'm not familiar with ADSK products, but if there's a need for people in that industry to use the software/if it's the "go to" software, then there's some degree of consistency/stability in that. ADSK is up nearly 400% in the last 5 years.

author: watermooses
body: Those companies buy all the small competitors with compelling products nowadays.  Throw Autodesk in there too.  They probably have more in house developers assigned to stitching software they buy into their own, than they have developing new software.

author: flobbley
body:
With my real money I do:

23% - FISVX (small-cap value index fund)

23% - FLCOX (large-cap value index fund)

23% - FNILX (large-cap index fund)

30% - FZILX (international excluding US index fund) 

With my fun money I'm currently in:

Autodesk - It's a good company with plenty of potential and proven growth

Cisco - I bought in to what I perceived to be an irrational dip last week, will probably sell soon and move into something else

Exelon - Same story as Cisco but a bit longer back, will probably also sell now that the ex-dividend date has passed

author: KimchiBaby1MoreTime
body:
>If you know any asphalt manufactures that may be a better play as repairing roads involves relaying sections of asphalt and filling in pot holes.

So... Cemex? OP did say they also manufactured asphalt.

[https://www.cemex.com/products-services/products/related-products](https://www.cemex.com/products-services/products/related-products)

&#x200B;

>Good luck to you, however as a civil engineer I can tell you we don't use concrete to repair bridges and roads.

I disagree with this statement. I'm also a civil engineer :) Concrete roads (which do exist, not all roads are asphalt) will need to be repaired with concrete. Many bridges are also constructed out of concrete (i.e. for the decks, piers, etc). Many bridges at the very least need repair to spalling concrete to mitigate potential issues from exposed rebar.

[https://kingcounty.gov/depts/local-services/roads/patton-bridge.aspx](https://kingcounty.gov/depts/local-services/roads/patton-bridge.aspx)

[https://mountainx.com/blogwire/bridge-repair-requires-i-40-to-i-240-ramp-closure/](https://mountainx.com/blogwire/bridge-repair-requires-i-40-to-i-240-ramp-closure/)

&#x200B;

>*This includes funding to improve air quality, limit greenhouse gas emissions...*  
>  
>Concrete is a huge producer of carbon dioxide emissions during manufacturing so that would be pretty ironic...

Your statement about CO2 emissions isn't wrong. However, Cemex has historically received funds from the United States for sustainability goals. So that quote on funding for greenhouse gas emissions research makes me even more bullish on Cemex.

[https://cementamericas.com/2020/11/16/cemex-awarded-doe-grant-for-carbon-capture-tech/](https://cementamericas.com/2020/11/16/cemex-awarded-doe-grant-for-carbon-capture-tech/)

[https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/BP-Cemex-to-partner-on-decarbonizing-cement-16173944.php](https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/BP-Cemex-to-partner-on-decarbonizing-cement-16173944.php)

[https://www.cemex.com/sustainability/climate-action/vertua-net-zero-carbon-concrete](https://www.cemex.com/sustainability/climate-action/vertua-net-zero-carbon-concrete)

&#x200B;

>If you want to try to make money off this then look at companies who do contract work for Highway Departments i.e civil engineering companies/contractors and companies engaged in the production and distribution of construction equipment and materials like asphalt, gravel, stone, sand, cranes, trucks, etc.

I agree. I'm also invested in some engineering firms (Arcadis, Jacobs, etc) and some engineering software (PTC, Autodesk, etc). But I am most overweight in Cemex. And so can you.

author: RationalExuberance7
body:
90% of my holdings, in order of largest to smallest. I think in 2 years it will look almost exactly the same (might get out of STNE soon)

SSD 

ADSK

BABA

BYDDF

STNE

author: Ka07iiC
body: It can look bad in the cash flows during transitions though. Adobe and Autodesk are huge Software businesses that both had ugly years in the switch from license to service model. Turned out great, and I think the same can happen to PLTR

author: jswb
body: I would remove autodesk - the professionals I know these days use Google Sketchup exclusively.

author: RationalExuberance7
body:
Companies that you can track not by looking at the price but by looking at the earnings, margin and competitive advantage - and also not able to be disrupted by new trends or technologies and able to maintain its competitive advantage easily against competition. Able to raise prices easily when faced with inflation. But most importantly - a company that you can have high confidence that it will be around in 20 years and will have similar or better qualities then. 

So I’d say...SSD, ADSK, DIS

author: pronkingxxx
body:
The idea that the companies in Ark have no solid fundamentals is perhaps the stupidest thing i've ever read.

Lets take a look at some of the holdings, you are telling me that:

Trimble, John Deere, NXP, Caterpillar, Komatsu, NVIDIA, Autodesk for just a quick glimpse of some of the more commonly known stocks in the portfolio are examples of reckless selections and have no solid fundamentals

author: PuffyPanda200
body:
First, I don't think that it requires 30 full time people to organize data. 

OK, so Palantir makes a tool that could be useful for analyzing data. There are a myriad of other tools to organize data. Having a program spit out the data in a .csv and then reading that data by another program is something I (a mechanical engineer with very limited programming knowledge) can do. 

Further, creating a tool to analyze data isn't justification for having a 40 B value and a currently negative P/E ratio. Autodesk creates the most ubiquitous CAD system, ANSYS creates the best all around FEA software. Neither of these companies are valued the way Palantir is.
